KMnO4 Oxidation works WONDERFULLY into shortening/converting the Alkyl chain on the
Aryl! For example Phenylpropane into Phenylacetic acid and then repeat the process until You get
Benzoic acid!) it is EXTREMELY SELECTIVE TOWARD Methyl and Carbxylic groups even if there are other moieties on the BOTH Ortho position! Plus it is not NEARLY AS toxic or complex as other methods!!! The interesting thing is that you need a kinda lot of it (KMnO4) and Epsom salt (Magnesium Sulphate Dodecahydrate) in the correct ratio to 1.) "activate" the reaction(somehow) most probably 2.)as s a Puffer 3.) to precipitate the product which could be either acidic or basic depending on conditions! like N-Xyl Orto-Toluinide! AND SOLVENT IS A GOOD OLD WATER!!!

TRICKY & BAD SIDE=You need a strong stirring plate, BE VERY PATIENT WHEN ADDING PERMANGANATE (FOAMS LIKE CRAZY, but if it has a green hue for a moment all is good!

You will need even better hot vacuum filtering technique GOOD SET OF FILTERS and some OR IT ALL TURNS INTO A MUD CAKE! I used some of the best filters available and, filter it at least 4 times, and there IT WAS STILL,
this ANNOYING MnO2 ultrafine sand even found its way into the main product EVEN AFTER VERY AGRESSIVE REDUCTION!

For the vanillin to primary amine, dissolve the vanillin in isopropanol. Add the hydroxylamine hydrochloride & amine + some NaOH to form oxime. Check reaction completion with TLC plating. Add conc. Ammonium hydroxide to neutralize. Heat rxn mix to 75° centigrade . Remove from heat & place rxn mix in secondary to prevent spill. Add 4 equiv powdered Zn to form 1° amine. Repeat 2x of 4 equiv powdered Zn , repeat once with 2 equiv powdered Zn. Zn will clump at bottom as rxn cools, so keep hot & repeat to ensure oxime is fully reacted. Remove Zn from rxn mix & work up w/reduced pressure evap or distillation.

Eliminates difficult recrystallization of oxime intermediate w/a 1 pot synthesis. I’ve gotten ~90% yields with an alkylated 3,5 dihydroxybenzaldehyde start material to bring benzaldehyde to 1° amine. If needed you could protect hydroxyl group on vanillin. Paper describing this procedure is on sci-finder.

NileRed. I'll give you an idea. Take a firewood and burn it down to ash then take that ash and mix it with H2O. After disollving ash in the water, take it and filtrate it. You're end with an very oily liquid. Take that liquid and pour it to a pot. Put that pot onto fire and wait. We need water to evaporate and what we'll end up is ~clean K2CO3. Be ready to end up scratching that thing, that will hardly come out of pot.
----------
K2CO3+2HCL --> 2KCL + CO2 + H2O
Water will be with us to the end of the whole process
Take Bleach (NaClO) and cook it without evaporating, we need water to stay here.
3NaClO --> 2NaCl + NaClO3
Filtrate crystalized NaCl + liquified NaClO3 through filter, for more purified NaClO3 go through that process a several times more.
After purifing our NaClO3 take it and mix it with KCl. Then put it in a fridge.
NaClO3+KCl --> KClO3 + NaCl
Our KClO3 will crystalize.
You'll end up with prety purify KClO3.
DANGER!!!! Do not try at home without specialized personal and gear.

NileRed should do "making capsaicin out of vanilla" video.  basically the compound that is responsible for vanillas smell and taste is vanillin and by doing a reductive amination with amonium formate he can make a capsaicin precursor. He can then do a wittig reaction with 6-bromohexanoic acid by adding triphenyl phosphine to it and then adding 2-methyl propanal as well as a strong base like potassium tert-butoxide to the mixture, which would make a product called 8-methyl-6-nonenoic acid. then by reacting the 1st capsaicin precursor with 8-methyl-6-nonenoic acid and adding acid as a catalyst, he can make capsaicin trough an amidification reaction. Capsaicin is the molecule that makes chilis spicy, so maybe he can try and add some to bell peppers to recreate spicy chili.

Hey Niles, great video, started it and couldn't stop watching till well past 1am on a workday.
Some thoughts :
- As a medicinal chemist in pharma, we use HATU all the time to make amide bonds. Peptide chemists use it less so cause it is known to racemize chiral amino acids. There are several ways or reagents you could also use to do this. Also DMF is really hard to wash away use a 5 wt% LiCl solution it helps pull DMF away from organic. One of my new favorite coupling reagents is Propanephosphonic acid anhydride, where the biproducts are just inorganic phosphate. You can also make the acyl chloride quite easily and cheaply and react with the amine (DCM, SOCl2).
- Heptane as you found out is a terrible solvent for extraction of organic molecules. Ethyl acetate or DCM are great.
- I've never tried acidifying my solutions with a stream of CO2! That was cool. If only climate deniers watched your video.
- I cant believe how small your NMR machine is! That will be a great tool for your future videos
- For hydrogentation sometimes you can get away doing transfer hydrogentation, where the hydrogen source is ammonium formate, but for me balloon always works well. Make sure you wet your Pd/C with some water or and bag it when disposing it, cause as it dries it can ignite again. I have seen several Pd/C fires in my time, (usually methanol, which is really hard to see)

Keep up the good work.

Then, after freebaseing the vanillyl amine HCl into vanillyl amine using NaOH, just react the isononanoyl chloride and vanillyl chloride to form the nordihydrocapsaicyn?
Also, for the oxidizing reagent, rather than jones reagent which takes a while to prepare, you could also use Potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) if KMnO4 didn’t work like in your case.

Materials:
Match Boxes (the more the better)
Test Tube (any container if you're poor)
Cotton Balls (nothing if you live life on the edge)
Optional/Reccomended: blow torch/lighter

1. Wet a cotton ball and dab it on the red striker pad of the match box

2. Scrape of the red striker part (red phosphorus) of the match box into your container/test tube

3. Stick a cottonball into the top of the container to trap the toxic fumes(white phosphorus)

4. Get matches/lighter/blow torch to heat up the bottom of the container

5. You know you've did it when gas starts to form inside the container

6. Optional: have someone breathe in the white phosphorus

I wince every time you use a sintered glass filter, in my experience you can never get them completely clean, and they're a massive source of contamination, unless you treat them as disposable items. Why can't you use one of them vac filter things where you put a sheet of disposable filter in it? They're normally called mobile phase filter systems. You can get all sorts of different filters for them, nylon, cellulose, glass fibre, paper, PTFE and so on.

I also saw something that has caused me many problems in the past, and it's that silicon vacuum grease! Not using it, cleaning all my ground glass connectors and using them dry fixed an issue I was having that was causing my product to have a really weird melting point profile. So, as inert as the stuff supposed to be, it does get into your solutions, it definitely causes issues with ID's via melting point as well. It would cause the product to look like it was melting, then stop having just got to where it looked kind of wet, then it melted and pooled at a higher temp, however it had blackened in between them two points. Utterly useless series of events really. Getting rid of the vacuum grease fixed the issue beautifully.

Really enjoy your channel though hey, I'd love my own lab like this, working in labs though I know it's an expensive endeavour!

You can attach pieces of the rubber hose or wrap the asbestos string around the metal ring where you put your separating funnel so you won't accidentally damage the glass.

Btw you shouldn't use water-cooled condenser if the boiling temperature of your chemical is above 150 C, you should use the air-cooled condenser. You can use the same condenser, just unplug the water. If you don't do it the apparatus will crack because of the difference between the temperatures of your compound and the water.

There is such a thing as an asbestos cloth. You can cover your bulb so the distillation will be much faster because the heat won't get out of the system. You can also cover the parts that are hard to heat with this cloth.

Isononanol is an alcohol. If anyone sells ADH and ALDH you could have potentially done the isononanoic acid reaction in two phases. These two enzymes can be used to turn ethanol into acetic acid and isopropanol into acetone. Though I can't find any medical or chemical data on how the reaction affects isononanol and there's the possibility that the reaction isn't a matter of turning an alcohol into an acid and is more of a matter of making it acetic, as can be seen with ethanol (-> acet ic acid) and isopropanol (-> acet one). Still worth a shot if there are synthetic sources of those enzymes.
Kinda intriguing that the Jones Reagent produces the same reaction with isopropyl as the ADH and ALDH process.

So I added the gloves to the solvent. Then I distilled the solvent. Then I poured the distillate into the separatory funnel. Then I dried it, but it looked wrong, so I added the solvent again and re-distilled. It looked better, so I poured the distillate into the separatory funnel, then dried it. Then I added the new solvent, put the new mixture in the separatory funnel, distilled the drained off solution, then dried it...
47 distillations, separations, and evaporations later....
And then I just threw a drop of it in the blender with some ingredients.

The HATU/DIPEA combo is one of the best reagents for making esters and amides at very high yield, which is crucial for peptide synthesis. They're quite expensive though, so for simple organic molecules like this one, you can use any of the dozens of other, cheaper options in the future (Like DCC or EDC with HOBt/DMAP, depending on solvent). Could even try simple Fischer esterification if you can afford a failure or two.

A few pointers: amides don’t usually dissolve in hexanes, you should do the final extraction in DCM, vanillyl amine is very prone to oxidation and open air distillation is a bad idea, anhydrous sodium sulfate in your steps were clearly not enough and generally mag sulfate is needed to pull water out of DCM, and never dump everything into the next step in a multistep synthesis unless you’ve personally made sure it had worked. Also is it cost prohibitive to run tlcs? Without tlcs you’re practically going blind. You don’t know if you’re getting the product and you don’t know if it’s completely reacted. Sincerely, a chem PhD.

Hi Nile, I have a feeling the reaction with KMnO4 didn’t work because your reactant (isononanol) is too apolar to dissolve the KMnO4, therefore making it quite inefficient. You would need to add a a water phase, as well as a phase transfer catalyst (such as Adogen 464) which is a quaternary ammonium salt with very long apolar tails. This can then continuously transfer permanganate anions to the organic phase to feed the oxidation.

Great video! Have you ever considered to do column cromatography to purify your chemicals? It can be a little tedious but it's a good option when distillation fails you. Also the TLC's accompanying it can help you gage the purity.

I only recently discovered this channel and it's given me a whole new perspective on chemistry especially as it relates to chemical engineering. I didn't take chem in college but took AP Chem in high school and I liked it but I honestly kind of viewed it as a "pure science" so to speak and did not really think of real world applications. It occurs to me that many of these synthesis projects are kind of like solving a rubik's cube (bear with me) -- you have a set of combinations that you can apply which are specially designed to affect certain parts of the cube without messing up the rest. You string these combinations together as needed until you get the cube into the state you want. His "combinations" are filtration, distillation, separation, etc. Another thought is how a lot of chemical engineering must be developing ever so slightly more efficient methods to save in material cost over large scale production... Anyway, been really enjoying the videos!

Capsaicin is itself a vanillin; its job is to prevent pepper seeds from rotting in the digestive tracts of animals so that those seeds are eventually dispersed. During the mutations that led to the creation of the class Mammalia, one random mutation to the trigeminal nerve results in our nervous system perceiving capsaicin as an irritant; no other class of animals respond to it as such.

A reptile or a bird will not find capsaicin repellent. Guess what they do find repellent, to the point of it being used commercially for perimeter control?


Methyl anthranilate aka natural/artificial Concord grape flavor, the other substance you derived from the same vinyl gloves, acting on –you guessed it– their trigeminal nerves.

Just a few questions: why didn't you turn the nonanoic acid into salt at the start during extraction by using sodium carbonate/bicarbonate?
Then you could add acid, precipitate the pure acid, and filter it.

HATU is a condensing agent, it is used in aminoacid chemistry to form peptide bonds. It's a aminoacid coupling agent.
Acil chlorides are never used in aminoacid chemistry, as they are far too reactive, they aren't selective and in the presence of base, they are prone to racemization( in the presence of bases, acil chlorides with alpha protons get turned into ketenes).
In the presence of HATU, a carboxylic acid forms something akin to an activated ester, which is more reactive than an ester, but much more selective than an acyl chloride.
Plenty of those activated esters and coupling reagents have been developed. 1-OH benzotriazole, DCCI( dicicloexyl carbodimmide), EDC, HATU, N-hydroxy succinime, DEPBT, etc.

You're doing an acylation of an amine with a milder acylating reagent, the process is the same as if you used isononanoyl chloride.
DIPEA Is diisopropiletil amine.

1. primary amine and aromatic amine are susceptible to oxidation, especially under high temperature.
2. rotavap with cooler and aspirator (reduce pressure distillation) will help you to recover most of the common solvent with 40 C water bath; of course, if you add argon atmosphere to the apparatus, it will even better.
3. Pd/C, H2 is not cheap and safe. Instead, NaBH4 in water/MeOH is much easier to operate.
4. Damn DEA and drug dealer, lots of chemicals are put under surveillance list now; such as P4 and HI.
5. The condensation is way too fancy; ester, amine, base under argon is much easier.
6. Prepare methyl ester, add amine to the ester, then add anhydrous NaOH/KOH as catalyst.
7. Heat it up under argon atmosphere.
8. Collect MeOH with the short path distillation.
9. Turn off heat, allow the hot mixture to slowly cooling down under argon atmosphere.
10. This procedure should be able to turn ester into amide without too much trouble in purification step.

Vanillin is pronounced similar to vanilla, because it was first derived from vanilla and it is what gives vanilla it's flavor.  The interesting thing here is that most vanilla flavoring doesn't actually come from vanilla, it comes from wood by converting lignan.  Since pure real vanilla is pretty expensive by comparison, your vanilla sugar was probably derived from wood.  So technically you went from wood and plastic gloves to hot sauce.

About the amide bond formation part (the last step), I think that dichloromethane (DCM, also polar and aprotic) might be a better choice of solvent for the reaction because it is easier to remove afterwards. Also, it might not be necessary to use HATU as the coupling reagent. I think that dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC) can be used, too.  DCC is way cheaper than HATU and the byproduct is insoluble in DCM, which would be easier to remove. However, HATU is one of the strongest coupling reagent so maybe the reaction really does need it. By the way, I highly recommend that the product should be purify with column chromatography. According to my experience, reactions that form amide bonds tend to also form some unknown impurities which I don't think it could be easily removed with extraction.

Just a cautious FYI for anyone making their own hot sauce: I didn't see Nile add any vinegar at the end (although there was some in the peppers). Botulonium toxin grows in anerobic environments greater than 4.7pH, and is commonly detected when people improperly preserving things like chopped garlic in oil. I don't imagine this sauce would be particularly safe to consume after a couple of weeks unless refrigerated. Also, be sure to sterilise whatever bottle you use!

As someone who makes their own naturally fermented hot sauces from scratch frankly this is kind of unnerving. Of course synthetic flavors have existed for ages, that's not the problem. Problem is that tons of people complain if a horrible metallic flavor in super hot extract based sauces. Synthetic Cap is primarily used in peppersprays, medical applications and yes...food as it is somehow cheaper to produce. This is now hard for me to fathom, since soxlet extraction can be done to produce it from the peppers themselves and ethanol can be recycled out and reused...strange all the way around and I don't blame you at all for poisoning concerns... Well done

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

Pairing the Hog Rider with the Balloon can deal devastating damage. If executed properly, the Hog Rider will act as a tank while the Balloon threatens to deal massive damage. The Hog Rider can also destroy any buildings attempting to slow down the combo. However, this combo is very vulnerable to swarms and anti-air cards as neither of the troops target anything but buildings. Additionally, they are easy to separate, due to the disparity in move speeds. Alternatively, the Hog Rider and the Balloon can be played in different lanes to spread the opponent's defenses thin. However, a building or Tornado can bring them back together for an easier defense.

The Hog Rider can be paired with the Lumberjack as both a swarm bait and damage combo. It is a very fast combo with an extremely high damage output potential, so the enemy will likely try to counter it with a swarm. If this happens, use a spell like Arrows to render the opponent defenseless. If they manage to defeat the Lumberjack, the dropped Rage will make the Hog Rider even more dangerous than it normally is.

A fast and deadly combination is the Hog Rider and Mini P.E.K.K.A. combo. Both units are fast but the Mini P.E.K.K.A. does much more damage and does not attack only buildings so the Mini P.E.K.K.A. can deal with troops like the Executioner and Musketeer. However, this combo can be defeated with swarms like Skeleton Army, which will defeat both of them since neither of them can deal area damage. They are also unable to target air troops, so the Minion Horde can stop this easily.

A risky play is to deploy the Hog Rider at the bridge as soon as the match starts. If the opponent does not react fast enough, the Hog Rider will deal a significant amount of damage to the Princess Tower. This can also allow the player to quickly scout the opponent's deck if they happen to react to him fast enough

Interesting, but no, capsaicin is not "the spicy molecule", it is "the picante molecule", which is something totally different. Cardamom is spicy. Cumin is spicy. Coriander is spicy. Cinnamon is spicy. Chili peppers, on the other hand, are not spicy, they're just picante. The difference is, spiciness is all smell, whereas picante is all "hot" mouth feel. That's why hot sauce is called "hot sauce" and not "spice sauce".

Had to look up Capsaicin, since that's the chemical I know that's what makes peppers spicy. I didn't know if your Nordihydrocapsaisin was in the family or the same thing. According to Wikipedia, it's the same molecule (Diagrams matched up), BUT, they used a different name: 8-methyl-N-vanillyl-6-nonenamide And would ya look at the component in the middle. It's like the person naming the stupid thing knew it was a relative of Vanillin or Vanillyl amine. Apparently not only is it in the Vanilloid Family, it works on some of the same receptors as the rest of the family (TRPV1) that tells the brain when something is burning or grinding up parts of the body, so that's why Capsaicin feels like fire. Drinking Alcohol creates a similar feeling, but through a different mechanism. (It changes the body's internal thermometer to report colder temperatures as being hot.)

Fun Stuff.

15 mins in, a couple of comments:

You need to start removing solvents under reduced pressure. removing your acetone by boiling it off on a hot-plate is not only a fire hazard it also could cause thermal decomposition of your product. Given that you do this a whole bunch, investing in a rotary evaporator would not only speed up the rate at which you could remove the solvent it would also speed your projects up by reducing the amount of product that you lose when removing solvent.

Also, dry your organic phase over somthing like magnesium suphate in order to remove the water, in an ideal world you'd also wash it with saturated brine first to pull as much water out of the organic phase as possible. It would have saved you from having to do the distillation twice.

Edit: At 17 mins you do this properly.

Edit: 31mins if you are going to do this reaction without using reflux apparatus, at least us a conical (erlenmeyer) flask, it's what they're designed for.

Edit: 47 minsYour inert atmosphere technique needs work. rubber septums and baloons, not just a quick squirt and a watch glass.

Edit: 53 mins That last extraction was textbook, really nice work, but, my point about the rotavap still stands, if you can afford a desktop NMR you can afford a rotary evaporator.

It's usually unreduced and > 5% Pd/C that tends to catch fire. Nowadays most of the Pd/C you buy is "reduced" which means it already has H2 absorbed onto it's surface. The act of absorbing H2 onto unreduced Pd/C or Pt/C for the first time is very exothermic and that creates the nice explosions when adding methanol :)

My two cents: HATU is awesome.
I've run a lot of very different amide couplings in my PhD, and always tried them with HATU at least once because it's so nice (usually gives pretty high yields and relatively pure products, it's not too difficult to purify out, and it doesn't smell as bad as some of the others).
Generally, amide couplings are extremely important in chemical biology - not exactly biochemistry, which has more to do with studying the reactions that occur in cells, the enzymes that catalyse them, etc. than with actually running syntheses; and particularly in peptide synthesis, as people have already mentioned in the comments.

Melting point is one of the least reliable metrics. Impurities can change the melting point by 10°C or more. There's also crystal polymorphs which are chemically identical but have different melting points, or even wide ranges.

Same with solubility. Small amounts of coproducts or impurities can prevent dissolution, or inhibit crystallization.

A heads up: it is better to use white vinegar or even rice vinegar to dilute capsaicin instead of alcohol, vinegar while helping with pH it also enhances a bit the flavour, specially when used with sweet things like those peppers or when used with ripe tomatoes. Not too much vinegar though if you're going to consume all the sauce in a short amount of time (a few days refrigerated) because even altough people in lots of places like their fresh sauce as acid as store bought hot sauce it takes a lot of the flavour.

By the way oil is a good thing in a hot sauce because it helps to create a sensation of lasting burning in the mouth which is what you're looking for instead of instant burn that goes away very quickly, in México there are some reaaally hot chiles called chiltepines or piquines (the small and round variety) that have that characteristic of burning like hell but in a minute or so the hotness goes away, unlike the habanero and other chiles that seem to perdure in the mouth.

Also consider using heptane instead of hexane in the future, it's not as bad for the environment as hexane. Heptane is also less toxic.

The reason you don't see anything crush out when treating vanillyl amine HCl with strong base is the phenolate will just start going into solution. A test would be to adjust to pH 6-7, extract with a bit of ether/dcm and evaporate. The oil left should have amine smell. Also especially in old papers they give melting points like this for compounds that decompose. 210-220 for a compound reported 219-221 is totally fine.

Hey Nile, why don't you buy a rotary evaporator to evaporate the solvents under reduced pressure?
It's much quicker and gentler than destilling it off at ambient pressure.

*addition: That's NOT how you do a reaction under inert or special atmosphere, I'm not sure what they taught you, but I would've added first the vanniline product - inert atmosphere - solvent (water and oxgen free) via syringe and finally under a small stream of Argon the Pd on carbon. If the Pd on Carbon doesn't react with the vanilline product you could even add them at the same time after you're put the flask under inert atmosphere. Maybe even suck out the Argon, put in the hydrogen and then add the solvent.

Your recipe in the last step works but it can get mouldy, you need to add some vinegar (or glacial acetic acid, you should have some lying around).
Spiciness can be quantified if you want, through the Scoville scale. Pure capsaicin is ~16M heat units; habanero, ~200k; jalapeño ~8k. So you could see some recipe online for hot sauce, calculate the expected spiceness based on ingredient weight, and use this as reference for how much capsaicin you should add. (You madman. To give you an idea, what you tasted is ten times worse than pepper spray.)

48:30
Just so you know... The orange oil could very well be the capsaicin.
I extracted capsaicin with isopropanol and washed it with water, to get out all water soluble stuff (which included a lot of color).
Adding water had the added bonus of dropping out the capsaicin, because the concentration of isopropanol wasn't high enough anymore.
A lot of orange brown thick oil/resin had separated out and stuck to the test tubes and I got rid of the water and isopropanol.
I washed the oil with more water to get rid of all the isopropanol.

I was left with what I guess was the capsaicin and it was dark orange...
I thought it was impure and there's a lot of the chili's color in it, but it might just be the natural color of it... I still was pretty disappointed. (Wrongly though...)

I have never tested my end product... It smelled gross and I was afraid it would just instantly kill my tongue 😂

53:30 the capsaicin seems to be very solvophile (attracting the solvent, a bit like hydrophilic compounds)
Which is the main reason I didn't want to test my product, since I could ingest a bunch of isopropanol... But then again I wouldn't eat much of the capsaicin anyways 😅😂
Better safe than sorry I guess...

I think I might still have it around somewhere, but I might just extract some more.

(Pro tip: if you have a snack thief at work, you can prepare an extra yummy looking snack with a potent amount of the capsaicin and the thief will reveal itself 😂👌)
(... Don't use too much of course... You don't want to seriously hurt anyone)

45:11 That's correct! HATU coupling is a pretty common and robust method for amide coupling. It's similar to DCC/DMAP coupling, except that HATU is basically like combining DCC with DMAP in one reagent. DIPEA (diisopropyl ethylamine) is just a general organic base to help the reaction along. It's common in biochemistry, since it's a mild method of forming peptides, but certainly in wide use in organic synthesis.

I am not sure if you will read this, but as a fellow chemist, I think what happened in the HATU reaction work up, is that you pulled some (or a lot) of the DMF in the EtAcO solution. DMF is a pain, and a good way to remove it is washing with a 10 % LiCl (aq) solution. Probably all the procedures you did afterward did the job, but probably you could have saved quite some time this way. BTW, HATU, HBTU, PyBOP are super common as peptide coupling agents, and if you work to some degree with peptides, it is common day use. Finally, was there a reason that you did not do a reductive amination with the vanillin? it seems like the easy way out, without needing to hydrogenate.

Definitely not worth it.
Fun Fact: nordihydrocapsaicin is 9,100,000 SHU. A Dragon’s Breath pepper (the hottest chili pepper in the world according to Guinness World Records) is only 2,480,000 SHU

I'm no chemist, but as a PhD student in virology, the reaction between the isononanoic acid and vanillyl amine hydrochloride looked like a condensation reaction leading to a peptide bond formation. Again I'm no chemist, but this happens everyday in our body as this is the way to build up amino acids into longer chains. I tried googling peptide bond formation protocol for fun and I found quite a bit of papers detailing many different ways to form the peptide bond. Perhaps this might be another way to make the chilli sauce?
